title: Don't Answer Strange Voices in the Night
body:
“Nancy…” it whispered.

I lay still in bed, sweat covering my body, terrified to move. I imagined that voice. It had to be a dream.

“Nancy,” it breathed into the dark, “come out here.”

Petrified, unable to move, it’s presence is palpable now.

I didn’t answer. Call it superstition. I recalled a story my brother told.

“Don’t ever reply to voices at night time. It’s evil spirits that want to come in,” my oldest brother had said.

This was a dumb Thai superstition he had been trying to scare our middle brother with. Instead, he scared me.

I had heard him through the wall, failing to whisper. I clutched my blanket around my head and tried to ignore the house speaking in creaks and groans that night. All to no avail.

 

That was years ago, long since forgotten, only now the memory has resurfaced. Whatever this is, it doesn’t sound like the usual voice of our house.

It sounds human, or as though it’s trying to be. It chitters as it paces in the moonlit hallway.

Muttering words that sound stolen from overheard conversation.

I can hear it's nails tapping and dragging, and I don't dare to breathe more oxygen than the bare necessity. Fearing what could happen if I accidentally communicate with it.

I learned years ago that the story wasn’t something my brother made up. It was a commonly held superstition in Thailand.

My mother confirmed as much the following day when I’d asked about it.

“It's true darling, but your brother shouldn't say these things. You don’t have to believe, but never offend the spirits” she stated, holding my young hands in hers.

She never found spiritual things funny, they were always serious. I understood now that to joke about them was to offend them. The consequences of offending a spirit weren't worth laughing over.

 

Even if she had never revealed this superstition to me, I wasn’t going to reply. That’s for damn sure. Nobody spoke English in this village, except for my family. None of which were supposed to be home.

And unlike the one that was slowly growing louder and closer to my door, I knew all their voices.

The hair on my neck prickled and I felt my skin ache in fear.

Praying to Gods I never worshipped. Making promises to them of devotion if they only helped me through this night.

Then my prayer worked. Help came in the form of my panting guardian scratching at the bed. Asking permission to join me.

I finally felt some of the fear lift. If he wasn't barking, then I was imagining things.

I ignored the previously perceived threat and patted beside me, “here boy”. My goofy hound jumping up at the invitation. He joined me on the blanket near my feet.

Only now I’m stuck here, blanket still over my head like when I was younger. Humidity rising, as I refuse to move anything but my thumbs to type. I haven't dared to look away from my phone.

It turns out that whatever I heard, is not my imagination. It knows I’m awake. It knows I can hear it murmuring.

And I think I just invited it into my bed.

Because I hear my dog barking. Loud and menacing, and I can hear him running outside my window.

Whatever is at the foot of my bed just whispered: “thank you for letting me in…”
author: TepidlyThai
